input: Enough for a chemo and infertility, is this a hereditary?
gold_answer: The cause of infertility is suspected to be immunological or genetic ; it may be that each partner is independently fertile but the couple can not conceive together.

retrieved_contexts.text:
Infertility
The main cause of male infertility is low semen quality . In men who have the necessary reproductive organs to procreate , infertility can be caused by low sperm count due to endocrine problems , drugs , radiation , or infection . There may be testicular malformations , hormone imbalance , or blockage of the man 's duct system . Although many of these can be treated through surgery or hormonal substitutions , some may be indefinite . Infertility associated with viable , but immotile sperm may be caused by primary ciliary dyskinesia . The sperm must provide the zygote with DNA , centrioles , and activation factor for the embryo to develop . A defect in any of these sperm structures may result in infertility that will not be detected by semen analysis . Antisperm antibodies cause immune infertility .
retrieved_contexts.title: Infertility

ml.tokens.model_text:
|user|: types and causes of male and female infertility
|assistant|: Here are the types and causes of male and female infertility: Male infertility can be caused by: 1. Low semen quality 2. Endocrine problems 3. Drugs 4. Radiation 5. Infection 6. Testicular malformations 7. Hormone imbalance 8. Blockage of the duct system 9. Primary ciliary dyskinesia 10. Antisperm antibodies Female infertility can be caused by: 1. Inability to ovulate 2. Malformation of the eggs 3. Polycystic ovarian syndrome 4. Failure of ovaries to mature and release eggs 5. Ovulatory problems These causes can be diagnosed and, in some cases, treated through medical intervention. However, in about 10-20% of cases, no cause is found.
|user|: How many years, think about adoption?
|assistant|: The documents do not include information on how long to consider adoption after experiencing infertility. This decision is often very personal and can depend on many factors.
|user|: Regional differences
|assistant|: The documents do not include information about regional differences in infertility types and causes.  Existing definitions of infertility lack uniformity , rendering comparisons in prevalence between countries or over time problematic . 
|user|: chemo and fertility,  before puberty, still?
|assistant|: The documents do not provide specific information about the impact of chemotherapy on fertility before puberty.   But, yes, chemotherapy can affect fertility.  It can cause DNA damaging of the cells in the testicles or ovaries that produce sperm and eggs, potentially leading to reduced fertility or even sterility.
|user|: any good idea to this?
|assistant|: While chemotherapy can impact fertility, there are options available to preserve fertility before starting treatment, such as sperm or egg freezing; eggs may be frozen and stored for later use.  For semen, cryopreservation can be used for far longer storage durations like 21 yrs.  However, these options may not be suitable for everyone, especially those who have not yet reached puberty.  It's important to discuss the potential risks and available options with a healthcare provider before starting chemotherapy.
|user|: Enough for a chemo and infertility, is this a hereditary?

retrieved_contexts.text:
Infertility
Antisperm antibodies ( ASA ) have been considered as infertility cause in around 10 -- 30 % of infertile couples . In both men and women , ASA production are directed against surface antigens on sperm , which can interfere with sperm motility and transport through the female reproductive tract , inhibiting capacitation and acrosome reaction , impaired fertilization , influence on the implantation process , and impaired growth and development of the embryo . Factors contributing to the formation of antisperm antibodies in women are disturbance of normal immunoregulatory mechanisms , infection , violation of the integrity of the mucous membranes , accidental rape and unprotected oral or anal sex . Risk factors for the formation of antisperm antibodies in men include the breakdown of the blood ‐ testis barrier , trauma and surgery , orchitis , varicocele , infections , prostatitis , testicular cancer , failure of immunosuppression and unprotected receptive anal or oral sex with men .
retrieved_contexts.title: Infertility

retrieved_contexts.text:
Infertility
In some cases , both the man and woman may be infertile or sub-fertile , and the couple 's infertility arises from the combination of these conditions . In other cases , the cause is suspected to be immunological or genetic ; it may be that each partner is independently fertile but the couple can not conceive together without assistance .
retrieved_contexts.title: Infertility
